{{distinguish|text=[[Escapology]], the art of escaping physical means of restraint}} {{other uses|Escapism (disambiguation)}} [[File:Lohengrin 1885.jpg|thumb|200px|King [[Ludwig II of Bavaria]] was an escapist who used to "escape" into the world of [[Wagner]]ian mythology.<ref>{{Cite book |last1= Workman |first1= Leslie J. |authorlink1= |title=Medievalism in Europe |series= |year= 1994 |publisher= Boydell & Brewer |isbn= 9780859914000 |pages= 241 }}</ref> A caricature portrays him as [[Lohengrin]].]]
'''Escapism''' is the avoidance of unpleasant, boring, arduous, scary, or banal aspects of [[Everyday life|daily life]].<ref>https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/escapism</ref> It can also be used as a term to define the actions people take to help relieve persistent feelings of [[Depression (mood)|depression]] or general [[sadness]].
==Perceptions== Entire industries have sprung up to foster a growing tendency of people to remove themselves from the rigors of daily life – especially into the digital world.<ref>G. Kainer, ''Grace and the Great Controversy'' (2010) p. 35</ref> Many activities that are normal parts of a healthy existence (e.g., eating, sleeping, exercise, sexual activity) can also become avenues of escapism when taken to extremes or out of proper context; and as a result the word "escapism" often carries a negative connotation, suggesting that escapists are unhappy, with an inability or unwillingness to connect meaningfully with the world and to take necessary action.<ref>D. Baggett et al, ''C. S. Lewis as Philosopher'' (2009) p. 260</ref> Indeed, the [[OED]] defined escapism as "The tendency to seek, or the practice of seeking, distraction from what normally has to be endured".<ref>Quoted in T. A. Shipley, ''The Road to Middle-Earth'' (1992) p. 285</ref>
However, many challenge the idea that escapism is fundamentally and exclusively negative. [[C. S. Lewis]] was fond of humorously remarking that the usual enemies of escape were jailers;<ref>G. Kainer, ''Grace and the Great Controversy'' (2010) p. 34</ref> and considered that used in moderation escapism could serve both to refresh and to expand the imaginative powers.<ref>D. Baggett et al, ''C. S. Lewis as Philosopher'' (2009) p. 260</ref> Similarly [[J. R. R. Tolkien]] argued for escapism in fantasy literature as the creative expression of reality within a secondary (imaginative) world, (but also emphasised that they required an element of horror in them, if they were not to be 'mere escapism').<ref>T. F. Nicolay, ''Tolkien and the Modernists'' (2014) p. 79 and p. 66</ref> [[Terry Pratchett]] considered that the twentieth century had seen the development over time of a more positive view of escapist literature.<ref>Terry Pratchett & Stephen Briggs, ''The Discworld Companion'' (2012) p. 329</ref> Apart from literature, [[music]] has been seen and valued as an artistic medium of escape, too.<ref>[[Andreas Dorschel]], ''Der Welt abhanden kommen. Über musikalischen Eskapismus''. In: ''Merkur'' 66 (2012), no. 2, pp. 135–142</ref>
==Psychological escapes== [[Sigmund Freud|Freud]] considered a quota of escapist [[Fantasy (psychology)|fantasy]] a necessary element in the life of humans: "[T]hey cannot subsist on the scanty satisfaction they can extort from reality. 'We simply cannot do without auxiliary constructions', [[Theodor Fontane]] once said".<ref>S, Freud, ''Introductory lectures on Psychoanalysis'' (PFL1) p. 419</ref> His followers saw rest and wish fulfilment (in small measures) as useful tools in adjusting to traumatic upset;<ref>[[Otto Fenichel]], ''The Psychoanalytic Theory of Neurosis'' (1946), p. 554</ref> while later psychologists have highlighted the role of vicarious distractions in shifting unwanted [[Mood (psychology)|moods]], especially anger and sadness.<ref>D. Goleman, ''Emotional Intelligence'' (1996) p. 73</ref>
However, if permanent residence is taken up in some such [[John Steiner (psychoanalyst)#Psychic retreat|psychic retreats]], the results will often be negative and even pathological.<ref>R. Britton, ''Belief and Imagination'' (2003) p. 119</ref> Drugs cause some forms of escapism which can occur when certain mind-altering drugs are taken which make the participant forget the reality of where they are or what they are meant to be doing.
==Escapist societies== Some social critics warn of attempts by the powers that control society to provide means of escapism instead of actually bettering the condition of the people – what [[Juvenal]] called “bread and the [[Gladiatorial games|games]]”.<ref>Juvenal, ''The Sixteen Satires'' (1982) p. 207</ref> Escapist societies appear often in literature. ''[[The Time Machine]]'' depicts the Eloi, a lackadaisical, insouciant race of the future, and the horror their happy lifestyle belies. The novel subtly criticizes [[capitalism]], or at least classism, as a means of escape. Escapist societies are common in dystopian novels; for example, in the ''[[Fahrenheit 451]]'' society, television and "seashell radios" are used to escape a life with strict regulations and the threat of a forthcoming war. In science fiction media escapism is often depicted as an extension of social evolution, as society becomes detached from physical reality and processing into a virtual one, examples include the virtual world of Oz in the 2009 Japanese animated science fiction anime ''[[Summer Wars]]'' and the game "Society" in the 2009 American science fiction film ''[[Gamer (2009 film)|Gamer]]'', a play on the real-life [[Massively multiplayer online game|MMO]] game ''[[Second Life]]''. Other escapist societies in literature include ''The Reality Bug'' by D. J. McHale, where an entire civilization leaves their world in ruin while they 'jump' into their perfect realities. The aim of the anti hero becomes a quest to make their realities seemingly less perfect in order to regain control over their dying planet.
Social philosopher [[Ernst Bloch]] wrote that utopias and images of fulfilment, however regressive they might be, also included an impetus for a radical social change. According to Bloch, social justice could not be realized without seeing things fundamentally differently. Something that is mere "daydreaming" or "escapism" from the viewpoint of a technological-rational society might be a seed for a new and more humane social order, as it can be seen as an "immature, but honest substitute for revolution".
==Escape scale==
The Norwegian psychologist Frode Stenseng has presented a dualistic model of escapism in relation to different types of activity engagements. He discusses the paradox that the flow state ([[Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi|Csikszentmihalyi]]) resembles psychological states obtainable through actions such as drug abuse, sexual masochism, and suicide ideation ([[Roy Baumeister|Baumeister]]). Accordingly, he deduces that the state of escape can have both positive and negative meanings and outcomes. Stenseng argues that there exist two forms of escapism with different affective outcomes dependent on the motivational focus that lies behind the immersion in the activity. Escapism in the form of self-suppression stems from motives to run away from unpleasant thoughts, self-perceptions, and emotions, whereas self-expansion stems from motives to gain positive experiences through the activity and to discover new aspects of self. Stenseng has developed the "escape scale" to measure self-suppression and self-expansion in people´s favorite activities, such as sports, arts, and gaming. Empirical investigations of the model have shown that:<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stenseng|first1=Frode|last2=Rise|first2=Jostein|last3=Kraft|first3=Pål|title=Activity Engagement as Escape from Self: The Role of Self-Suppression and Self-Expansion|journal=Leisure Sciences: An Interdisciplinary Journal|date=2012|volume=34|issue=1|pages=19–38|doi=10.1080/01490400.2012.633849|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/01490400.2012.633849}}</ref> * the two dimensions are distinctively different with regard to affective outcomes * some individuals are more prone to engage through one type of escapism * situational levels of well-being affect the type of escapism that becomes dominant at a specific time
==During the Great Depression== [[Alan Brinkley]], author of ''Culture and Politics in the Great Depression'', presents how escapism became the new trend for dealing with the hardships created by [[Great Depression|the stock market crash in 1929]]: magazines, radio and movies, all were aimed to help people mentally escape from the mass poverty and economic downturn. ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine, which became hugely popular during the 1930s, was said to have pictures that give "no indication that there was such a thing as depression; most of the pictures are of bathing beauties and ship launchings and building projects and sports heroes – of almost anything but poverty and unemployment”. Famous director [[Preston Sturges]] aimed to validate this notion by creating a film called ''[[Sullivan's Travels]]''. The film ends with a group of poor destitute men in jail watching a comedic [[Mickey Mouse]] [[cartoon]] that ultimately lifts their spirits. Sturges aims to point out how "foolish and vain and self-indulgent" it would be to make a film about suffering. Therefore, movies of the time more often than not focused on comedic plot lines that distanced people emotionally from the horrors that were occurring all around them. These films "consciously, deliberately set out to divert people from their problems", but it also diverted them from the problems of those around them.<ref>Brinkley, Alan. Culture and Politics in the Great Depression. Waco, Tx: Markham Press Fund, 1999. http://www.uvm.edu/~pblackme/Brinkley.pdf</ref>

{{Tone|date=September 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox character | colour = #191970 | name = Hannah Baker | series = [[Thirteen Reasons Why]] | portrayer = [[Katherine Langford]] | creator = [[Jay Asher]] | lbl22 = Birthday | data22 = August 28, 2000 | image = Katherine Langford as Hannah Baker.jpg | caption = [[Katherine Langford]] as Hannah Baker | first = '''Novel''':
"Cassette 1: Side A" (2007)
'''Television''':

'''Television''':
“Bye” (2018) | occupation = Student | gender = Female | family = Andy Baker (father)
Olivia Baker (mother) }} '''Hannah Baker''' is a [[Character (arts)|fictional character]] created by American author [[Jay Asher]]. She is the subject of his 2007 [[young adult fiction]] mystery novel ''[[Thirteen Reasons Why]]'', which was adapted by the media company [[Netflix]] as ''[[13 Reasons Why]]''. Hannah is introduced as a [[sophomore]] at the fictional Liberty High School; she struggles to adjust to living in an unsympathetic school environment. In the television series, Hannah is portrayed by Australian actress [[Katherine Langford]], who returned for the show's second season, which was released in 2018.{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/13-reasons-two-new-cast-10396457 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-12-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171226130848/http://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/13-reasons-two-new-cast-10396457 |archivedate=December 26, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} "When is 13 Reasons Why season 2? Release date, spoilers, new cast and whether Hannah will return" ''13 Reasons Why'' received largely positive, though also polarizing, reviews from critics and audiences. Although critics were divided on several aspects of the show, in particular how it handled mental health and its depictions of rape and suicide, they praised Langford's performance. Langford later received a [[Golden Globe Award]] nomination for her performance. She was catapulted to worldwide attention and was variously called "a revelation",{{cite web|first=Daniel|last=Montgomery|url=https://www.goldderby.com/article/2017/katherine-langford-13-reasons-why-emmy-awards/|title=Emmy spotlight: Newcomer Katherine Langford (’13 Reasons Why’) is a revelation as a suicidal teen|website=[[Gold Derby Awards]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=April 10, 2017|accessdate=August 28, 2018}} "believable and raw",{{cite web|first=Liz Shannon|last=Miller|url=https://www.indiewire.com/2017/03/13-reasons-why-review-netflix-suicide-1201799484/|title=’13 Reasons Why’ Review: Netflix Brings a Brutally Adult Edge to A Tale of Teen Suicide|website=[[Indiewire]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=August 28, 2018}} and "magnetic".{{cite magazine|first=Sophie|last=Gilbert|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2018/05/13-reasons-why-season-two-netflix/560426/|magazine=[[The Atlantic]]|publisher=[[Emerson Collective]]|location=Boston, Massachusetts|date=May 17, 2018|accessdate=August 28, 2018}} Daniel Montgomery of the [[Gold Derby Awards|Gold Derby]] said she was an early frontrunner for an [[Emmy Award]] nomination. ==Storyline (television series)== At the beginning of the series, 17-year-old schoolgirl Hannah Baker commits suicide by slitting her wrists—in the novel she swallows and overdoses on pills. Her school locker becomes a memorial adorned with students' letters and her pictures. On his doorstep, Hannah's friend [[Clay Jensen]] finds a box containing [[Compact Cassette|audio cassette tapes]] containing a recording of Hannah talking about the 13 reasons for her suicide. Clay listens to the first tape, on which Hannah narrates the events that led to her suicide. She talks about her first kiss with Justin Foley, who later spreads a rumour about their encounter. Justin's friend [[Bryce Walker]] forwards Hannah's private photograph from his phone to everyone at school, further embarrassing her. Clay recalls being rude to Hannah about her leaked photograph. Each subsequent tape reveals the thirteen reasons she killed herself. Hannah warns listeners to follow certain rules; everyone mentioned on the tapes must listen to the complete set then pass it along to the next person addressed. If they fail to do so, the second set of tapes, held by personal friend Tony, who is not on the tapes, will be released. Clay, who was secretly in love with Hannah, reminisces about the time he spent with her. He finds listening to Hannah's story difficult, but his friend Tony finds him and reveals he helped Hannah record the tapes and knows Clay is mentioned on them. He warns Clay things will go wrong if he does not obey the tapes.{{cite magazine|first=Shirlley|last=Li|title=Episode 1: "Tape 1, Side A"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=April 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170413074236/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/|archivedate=April 13, 2017|df=mdy-all}} On the B side of the first tape, Hannah talks about her friendship with Jessica Davis and Alex Standall, who later start dating and stop hanging out with Hannah. When Alex breaks up with Jessica, she blames Hannah for the breakup and slaps her in public.{{cite web|first=Shirlley|last=Li|title=Episode 2: "Tape 1, Side B"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/2/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=April 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170413073512/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/2/|archivedate=April 13, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Alex is the subject of the A side of the second tape. In the present, Hannah's mother, Olivia Baker, finds the "hot or not" list, on which Hannah was voted as the "best ass", at her house, leading her to believe her daughter was being bullied. She seeks the school principal's help. Clay turns to Alex for answers and reveals that Alex made the list to get back at Jessica, who refused to have sex with him. What Alex did not know, is that his list has led to Hannah being touched by unknown boys sexually and finally being raped by Bryce.{{cite web|last=Li|first=Shirlley|title=Episode 3: "Tape 2, Side A"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/3/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=new York City|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=April 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170413073811/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/3/|archivedate=April 13, 2017|df=mdy-all}} As Clay progresses through the tapes, he encounters the other people mentioned on Hannah's recordings. He discovers everyone on the tapes either took advantage of Hannah or abandoned her. Tyler Down, the school photographer, stalks Hannah and distributes a photograph of her and her only friend Courtney Crimsen kissing.{{cite magazine|first=Ruth|last=Kinane|title=Episode 4: "Tape 2, Side B"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/4/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=April 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415203801/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/4/|archivedate=April 15, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Afraid of her classmates discovering that she is a [[lesbian]], Courtney spreads a rumor that the girls in the leaked photos are Hannah and Laura, another lesbian classmate, and adds to the rumor about Hannah and Justin.{{cite web|first=Ruth|last=Kinane|title=Episode 5: "Tape 3, Side A"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/5/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|accessdate=15 April 2017|date=31 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415203352/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/5/|archivedate=April 15, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Marcus Cole humiliates Hannah in public,{{cite web|first=Ruth|last=Kinane|title=Episode 6: "Tape 3, Side B"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/6/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=April 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415205615/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/6/|archivedate=April 15, 2017|df=mdy-all}} and Zach Dempsey steals her class notes as revenge for her rejecting him.{{cite magazine|first=Isabella|last=Biedenharn|title=Episode 7: "Tape 4, Side A"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/7/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=April 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415203907/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/7/|archivedate=April 15, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Hannah later joins a poetry club where she meets the student Ryan Shaver, who publishes her personal poem against her wishes in his school magazine "Lost'n Found".{{cite web|last=Biedenharn|first=Isabella|title=Episode 8: "Tape 4, Side B"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/8/|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=15 April 2017|date=31 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415205616/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/8/|archivedate=April 15, 2017|df=mdy-all}}In the present day, Tony confides in Clay about the night of Hannah's death. Hannah attends a party at Jessica's house; while hiding in Jessica's room, Hannah watches Bryce rape a drunk, unconscious Jessica, with Justin's complicity.{{cite magazine|first=Isabella|last=Biedenharn|title=Episode 9: "Tape 5, Side A"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/9/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=April 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415203922/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/9/|archivedate=April 15, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Hannah is afraid to tell anyone and decides to leave. Sheri Holland, the subject of the next tape, offers Hannah a ride home but abandons her after crashing her car into a stop sign and refusing to report it, which later leads to the death of Jeff Atkins.{{cite magazine|first=Isabella|last=Biedenharn|title=Episode 10: "Tape 5, Side B"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/10/|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=April 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415203611/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/10/|archivedate=April 15, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Clay struggles to continue listening to Hannah's recordings, thinking he has let her down. He decides to return the tapes to Tony, who tells him he is the subject of the next tape. Clay hesitates to listen to "his" tape, but decides to continue.{{cite web|last=Highfill|first=Samantha|title=Episode 11: "Tape 6, Side A"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/11/|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=15 April 2017|date=31 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415203306/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/11/|archivedate=April 15, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Hannah continues to talk about the night of Jessica's party. Hoping for a fresh start to the school year, she wants to admit to her feelings for Clay. The two spend most of the time together at the party and kiss in Jessica's room. Hannah is overwhelmed by the memories of her previous encounters with boys at school, which include Justin, Marcus and Zach. She screams at Clay and asks him to leave. Thinking he has provoked Hannah's breakdown, Clay leaves her alone in the room. Hannah witnesses Bryce raping Jessica. Hannah says though Clay does not deserve to be on the tapes, she could not have told her story without talking about him. On the B side of tape 6, Hannah talks of "the most difficult day" of her life.In the present day, Olivia finds a list with all the names of the people on the tapes, but does not know the meaning behind them. The Bakers decide to file a lawsuit against the school and everyone on the list is subpoenaed. After accidentally losing her parent's deposits, which were supposed to go to the bank, Hannah's parents angrily confront her, later that night, after feeling extremely depressed and a burden to everyone around her, she goes to a party at Bryce's house, after being peer pressured to join in the hot tub, Hannah unfortunately finds herself alone with Bryce, who proceeds to rape her. After returning home Hannah starts recalling how her life came to this point, and after writing down a list of the people who hurt her, she decides that "No one will hurt her again". .{{cite web|last=Highfill|first=Samantha|title=Episode 12: "Tape 6, Side B"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/12/|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=15 April 2017|date=31 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415205618/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/12/|archivedate=April 15, 2017|df=mdy-all}} On the final tape, Hannah recalls the day of her suicide. She records 12 tapes, starting with Jessica, and ending with Bryce, after recording the tapes, Hannah said she felt "Something shift", and decides to get help and give life one more try. She visits school counselor Mr. Porter and asks for his help, and tells him about the rape but refuses to disclose her rapist's identity, after failing to extract the boy's name, Mr. Porter tells her to "Move on". Hannah leaves his office, in hopes of him following her, he doesn't. Hannah drops off her uniform on the counter at the Crestmont before delivering the tapes to Tony. Hannah returns home, cleans her room and put on old clothing, she fills up her bathtub and slits her wrists with a razor blade. Hannah dies of blood loss and is found by her parents, who attempt to save her by calling 911 but are too late.{{cite web|last=Highfill|first=Samantha|title=Episode 13: "Tape 7, Side A"|url=http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/13/|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=15 April 2017|date=31 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170415204029/http://ew.com/recap/13-reasons-why-season-1/13/|archivedate=April 15, 2017|df=mdy-all}} ==Development== ===Characterization=== {{quote box|width=25em|In the scenes where Clay remembers Hannah being alive, his world is full of bright and vibrant colours, but when he is brought back to a reality without Hannah in it, his world is much darker, full of harsher shades of blue and grey.|—Caitlin Hacker, writing on the use of different camera for filters depicting life before and after Hannah's death, [[Popsugar]]{{cite web|last1=Hacker|first1=Caitlin|title=13 Reasons Why: The 1 Detail About Hannah's Death You Might Have Missed|url=https://www.popsugar.com/entertainment/13-Reasons-Why-Different-Color-After-Hannah-Death-43423154|publisher=[[Popsugar]]|accessdate=22 April 2017|date=15 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170422023637/https://www.popsugar.com/entertainment/13-Reasons-Why-Different-Color-After-Hannah-Death-43423154|archivedate=April 22, 2017|df=mdy-all}}}} Asher's book was criticized for the poor characterization of Hannah Baker, which many critics said the television series improved upon.{{cite web|last1=Donaldson|first1=Kayleigh|title=Netflix's 13 Reasons why TV Show is Better Than the Book|url=http://screenrant.com/13-reasons-why-tv-show-better-book/|website=ScreenRant|accessdate=20 April 2017|date=4 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170421001145/http://screenrant.com/13-reasons-why-tv-show-better-book/|archivedate=April 21, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|last1=Thompson|first1=Eliza|title=15 Differences Between Netflix's 13 Reasons Why and the Book|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/entertainment/tv/a9224403/13-reasons-why-book-vs-show/|work=[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]|accessdate=17 April 2017|date=4 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170418081530/http://www.cosmopolitan.com/entertainment/tv/a9224403/13-reasons-why-book-vs-show/|archivedate=April 18, 2017|df=mdy-all}} In her book review for ''[[The Guardian]]'', Katherine Hughes wrote that Hannah "comes across not so much as a young soul in distress as a vengeful harpy".{{cite web|last1=Hughes|first1=Katherine|title=Thirteen Reasons Why by Jay Asher|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/jan/23/thirteen-reason-why-jay-asher|website=The Guardian|accessdate=19 April 2017|date=23 January 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170419192114/https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/jan/23/thirteen-reason-why-jay-asher|archivedate=April 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The character was inspired by one of Asher’s relatives, who had tried to commit suicide.{{cite news|last1=Ricj|first1=Motoko|title=A Story of a Teenager’s Suicide Quietly Becomes a Best Seller|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/10/books/10why.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=17 April 2017|date=9 March 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170418000100/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/10/books/10why.html|archivedate=April 18, 2017|df=mdy-all}} At the beginning to the series, Hannah is a 16-year-old high school junior, "from a white picket fence town with an almost perfect family".{{cite web|last1=Curtis|first1=Alexa|title=Dies '13 Reasons Why' Glamorize Teen Suicide?|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/tv/features/does-13-reasons-why-glamorize-teen-suicide-w476303|website=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=17 April 2017|date=14 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170416014452/http://www.rollingstone.com/tv/features/does-13-reasons-why-glamorize-teen-suicide-w476303|archivedate=April 16, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Noting the realism and relatability of the character with real-life people, Quinn Keaney of [[Popsugar]] wrote that Hannah, "is just like you ... like someone you know; she's smart, she has a bright future ahead of herself, she has loving parents, she just wants to be liked".{{cite web|last1=Keaney|first1=Quinn|title=In Praise of the Unflinchingly Honest Approach to Teen Suicide on 13 Reasons Why|url=https://www.popsugar.co.uk/celebrity/How-Does-Hannah-Kill-Herself-13-Reasons-Why-43383360|publisher=Popsugar|accessdate=20 April 2017|date=2 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170418144618/https://www.popsugar.co.uk/celebrity/How-Does-Hannah-Kill-Herself-13-Reasons-Why-43383360|archivedate=April 18, 2017|df=mdy-all}} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''{{'}}s Maureen Ryan offered a similar observation on the realistic portrayal of teenagers, writing that the "darkness" in Hannah's life is "constantly interwoven with the natural resilience and questioning optimism of adolescence".{{cite web|last1=Ryan|title=TV Review: ‘13 Reasons Why’ on Netflix|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/reviews/13-reasons-why-review-netflix-selena-gomez-dylan-minnette-katherine-langford-1202013547/|website=Variety|accessdate=20 April 2017|date=21 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170407144809/https://variety.com/2017/tv/reviews/13-reasons-why-review-netflix-selena-gomez-dylan-minnette-katherine-langford-1202013547/|archivedate=April 7, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Writing for ''[[TVLine]]'', Andy Swift described her as "a fresh-faced teen with a bright future",{{cite web|last1=Swift|first1=Andy|title=Netflix's 13 Reasons Why Premiere: Will {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Albert Gleizes, 1912, Le Dépiquage des Moissons, Harvest Threshing, oil on canvas, 269 x 353 cm, National Museum of Western Art, Tokyo, Japan.jpg | image_size=420px | title=Harvest Threshing | other_language_1=French | other_title_1=Le Dépiquage des Moissons | artist=[[Albert Gleizes]] | year=1912 | medium=Oil on canvas | height_metric=269 | width_metric=353 | height_imperial=105.9 | width_imperial=139 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Tokyo]] | museum=[[National Museum of Western Art]] }} '''''Le Dépiquage des Moissons''''', also known as '''''Harvest Threshing''''', and '''''The Harvesters''''', is an immense oil painting created in 1912 by the French artist, theorist and writer [[Albert Gleizes]] (1881–1953). It was first revealed to the general public at the Salon de la [[Section d'Or]], ''Galerie La Boétie'' in Paris, October 1912 (no. 43). This work, along with ''La Ville de Paris'' (''City of Paris'') by [[Robert Delaunay]], is the largest and most ambitious [[Cubism|Cubist]] painting undertaken during the pre-War Cubist period. Formerly in the collection of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York, this monumental painting by Gleizes is exhibited at the [[National Museum of Western Art]], in Tokyo, Japan. ==Description== The work is an oil painting on canvas with dimensions 269 x 353 cm (106 x 138 in), signed and dated lower right, Gleizes, 1912. "''Harvest Threshing''", wrote curator and art historian [[Daniel Robbins (art historian)|Daniel Robbins]] for the Gleizes Guggenheim Retrospective in 1964, "summarizes Gleizes' interest in presenting an epic panorama of mountains, valleys, clouds and smoke, towns, workers and wheat, a simultaneous celebration of the harvest, nature and man in idealistic harmony." Gleizes' painting, as [[Henri Le Fauconnier]]'s ''Abundance'', likely takes its theme from the social and synthetic program of the [[Abbaye de Créteil]], and too, from the poem of [[:fr:Henri-Martin Barzun|Henri-Martin Barzun]], ''La Montagne, Poèmes légendaires'', part 5 of ''La Terrestre Tragedie'' (Paris, Mercure de France, 1908): ''Les Moissonneurs dans les Epis, armes de faux et de faucilles...'' (pp. 49–56).[https://archive.org/stream/albertgleizes1881robb#page/n3/mode/2up Daniel Robbins, 1964, ''Albert Gleizes 1881 - 1953, A Retrospective Exhibition'', Published by The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, New York, in collaboration with Musée National d'Art Moderne, Paris, Museum am Ostwall, Dortmund.] [[File:Meudon, Panorama de Meudon, Issy-les-Moulineaux et Paris, Vue prise de la Terrasse de Meudon.jpg|thumb|right|Panorama Meudon, Issy-les-Moulineaux and Paris, View from Terrasse de Meudon, early 20th-century postcard]] [[File:La Moisson, C.L.C. 3.jpg|thumb|right|La Moisson, C.L.C, early 20th-century postcard]] While the [[still-life]] and [[nude]] are common themes of pre-[[World War I]] Cubism, the work of Gleizes is characterized by ambitious subjects:[http://www.peterbrooke.org.uk/a%26r/Du%20Cubisme/contents Peter Brooke, ''On "Cubism" in context'', 2012] the harvest, the hunt, the city, and, later, ''Broadway'' in New York City, and the ''Brooklyn Bridge'' (1915, Guggenheim, New York), one of his most abstract paintings of this period.[http://www.moma.org/collection/artist.php?artist_id=2191 Daniel Robbins, MoMA, Oxford University Press] Gleizes took this, according to Peter Brooke, as symbolic of the need to express the whole vast drama, the collection of unprecedented sensations of modern life. ''Harvest Threshing'' represents a big subject, rich in plastic possibilities. The interest of the painting resides in its rich and complex fabric of interwoven latticework, with 'the institution of relations between straight lines and curves' or the 'thousand surprises of fire and of shadow' proposed in ''[[Du "Cubisme"]]'' (co-authored with [[Jean Metzinger]] in 1912). The subject matter is entirely, as Le Fauconnier and Gleizes himself says, 'a pretext'. A pencil transcription done to scale by Geneviève Dalban, as Peter Brooke points out, reveals the greatness of the construction. "The 'duration' that has been so much talked about is entirely a matter of the length of time that can be spent looking at it, as one thing leads to another, in and out and round about, in an endless visual dance. It is a mark of the failure of the Cubist revolution – its hi-jacking by the champions of the subject – that nearly one hundred years later there are writers on art who can see in such a picture only peasants, a church tower, a rustic meal, mountains, clouds..." ==Background== [[File:CPA 54 Longwy Bas vue générale, Longwy a Longuyon, usines, 1904.jpg|thumb|right|Longwy Bas vue générale, Longwy a Longuyon, usines, 1904, postcard]] [[File:Oeuvre Parisienne des Enfants a la Montagne. C'est la Moisson.jpg|thumb|right|Oeuvre Parisienne des Enfants a la Montagne. C'est la Moisson, early 20th-century postcard]] In this painting can be observed the summing up of all present in the art of [[Georges Seurat]]: "the line, independent of its topographical role, possesses an assessable abstract value", it represented the furthest extension of [[Paul Cézanne]]'s preoccupations: his will to deconstruct, his revolt against imitation and refusal of Renaissance perspective.[http://Cubism-coldcreation.blogspot.com Alex Mittelmannn, ''State of the Modern Art World, The Essence of Cubism and its Evolution in Time'', 2011] Much as that of ''[[Les Baigneuses (Gleizes)|Les Baigneuses]]'' and ''[[Man on a Balcony (Gleizes)|Man on a Balcony (Portrait of Dr. Théo Morinaud)]]'' painted the same year, the subject matter of ''Harvest Threshing''—a semi-urban landscape that possesses both rural and semi-industrial components, juxtaposing sharply contrasting elements of both traditional and modern life—is derived from an unsentimental observation of the world. On the one hand the artist makes illusion to the traditional process of [[threshing]]—a step in grain preparation after [[harvest]]ing and before [[winnowing]], now mostly done by machine—and on the other, the artist includes elements from a society in the process of inexorable industrialization. Yet the compositional relationships between the two are formally resolved. The representation of this transition between classical tradition and contemporary life was noticeably of interest to Gleizes, as it was to other artists of the [[Section d'Or]]. "The organic process of life and civilization, moving irresistibly toward harmonious interaction," wrote [[Daniel Robbins (art historian)|Robbins]], "was the subject of Gleizes' art." It was treated neither as a "confined symbolic allegory nor as a cultural background indicated by specific real appearance, but was instead presented in concrete and precise terms. Gleizes' ''Harvest Threshing'', the masterpiece of the Section d'Or (no. 34), is not merely an anecdote in a scene. Rather, it is a multiple panorama celebrating the worker, his material life and his collective activity in securing that life on a permanently changing land. Gleizes confronts us not with one action or place, but with many: not with one time, but with past and future as well as present."(Robbins, 1964) ==In contrast to Picasso and Braque== [[File:Braque fruitdish glass.jpg|thumb|left|130px|[[Georges Braque]], ''Fruitdish and Glass'', [[papier collé]] and charcoal on paper, 1912]] [[File:L'Aveyron, Decazeville, 1918, Les Usines, CPA.jpg|thumb|right|L'Aveyron, Decazeville, 1918, Les Usines, postcard]] Gleizes had no intention of analyzing and describing neutral objects from daily life; a bowl of fruit, a pipe, violin or guitar. His 'empathetic' consciousness and complex idealistic concepts of the world led him to portray—rather than 'mundane' objects—subjects of vast proportion, of provocative social and cultural significance. For Gleizes, consciousness and reality could meet and reconcile on the surface of the canvas. There is no period that corresponds closely to the analytic Cubism developed by Picasso and Braque in the work of Gleizes, as of Delaunay, Le Fauconnier and [[Fernand Léger|Léger]]. The ''iconography'' of these artists, in contrast to that of Picasso and Braque, helps elucidate the reasons. At the same time, iconography explains how Gleizes and Delaunay were to become abstract painters, theoretically closer to [[Wassily Kandinsky]] and [[Piet Mondrian]] than to Picasso, Braque or even [[Juan Gris|Gris]]. The intention of Gleizes had been to reconstitute and synthesize the real-world according to his own consciousness. Important factors in this process were the relationships and interactions between volumes to convey solidity, structure, weight, placement. Also important was a principal lessons of Cézanne: the indivisibility of form and color; a change in one would alter the other. Unlike Picasso and Braque, the work of Gleizes always involved the synthetic treatment of broad subjects, each section of canvas receiving equal attention. As a consequence, almost a year after the completion of ''The Harvesters'', Gleizes would develop compositional innovations: broad tilting planes that provide a transition from the outer rectangles to the rotating forms at the core of the work. Gleizes was aware of the differences between his own interests and those of Picasso and Braque. He wrote an article after seeing Picasso's work for the first time (in 1911). After quoting Apollinaire about returning to the principles of structure, color and inspiration, he wrote that the "valuable [precieuses] indications of Picasso and Braque, in spite of everything, did not depart from an impressionism of form which, nevertheless, they opposed (an impressionism of) color." ==''Du "Cubisme"''== [[Image:Albert Gleizes, l'Homme au Balcon, 1912, oil on canvas, 195.6 x 114.9 cm, Philadelphia Museum of Art.jpg|thumb|150px|Albert Gleizes, 1912, ''[[Man on a Balcony (Gleizes)|l'Homme au Balcon, Man on a Balcony (Portrait of Dr. Théo Morinaud)]]'', oil on canvas, 195.6 x 114.9 cm (77 x 45 1/4 in.), [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]]. Exhibited at Salon d'Automne, Paris, 1912, [[Armory show]], New York, Chicago, Boston, 1913. The setting: an urban backdrop of bridge-girders, smokestacks and train tracks viewed from the balcony of a surgeon's office, avenue de l'Opéra, Paris]] In preparation for the Salon de la Section d'Or, and in the wake of their controversial showing at the Salon des Indépendants in the spring of 1911, Albert Gleizes and [[Jean Metzinger]] published a major defense of Cubism and the first theoretical essay on the new movement, entitled ''[[Du "Cubisme"]]''. Passages of their text which attempted to reconcile goals and methods of modern painting were read to the circle around the Duchamp brothers (the Puteaux group) during the summer of 1912 and it was published before the conclusion of the Salon de la Section d’Or, where Gleizes exhibited his monumental Cubist painting ''The Harvesters''. Gleizes believed that artists could explain themselves in writing as well as (or better than) critics. He continued writing throughout the following years as ''Du "Cubisme"'' enjoyed wide circulation within a continuously growing circle of artists and connoisseurs. By placing the artist at the centre of society, Albert Gleizes, along with a generation of painters from diverse classes and nations, helped revolutionize the bourgeois canons. By observing and thinking, as opposed to serving solely as an ornamenter, Gleizes concluded, the artist realized a fundamental service to humanity. Shortly after the 1912 publication of ''[[Du "Cubisme"]]'', Guillaume Apollinaire published ''Les Peintres Cubiste'' (1913, written in 1912), in which he wrote "Majesty: this is what, above all, characterizes the art of Albert Gleizes. [...] This majesty arouses and provokes the imagination; considered from the plastic point of view, it is the immensity of things. [...] The pictures of Albert Gleizes are realized by a force of the same sort as that which realized the Pyramids and the Cathedrals, the constructions in metal, the bridges and the tunnels."Guillaume Apollinaire, ''Aesthetic Meditations on Painting, The Cubist Painters'' (Second Series), written in 1912, published in 1913 (Edition Figuière, Paris), translated and published in [http://dl.lib.brown.edu/mjp/render.php?id=1299781650906252&view=mjp_object ''The Little Review'', Quarterly Journal of art and letters, ''Stella Number'', Autumn 1922, New York, London] (Administration; Margaret Anderson, Francis Picabia and Ezra Pound). ==Provenance== * Solomon R. Guggenheim (acquired from the artist in 1938)
At the outset of 1938, Gleizes learned that the religious community that owned Moly Sabata, a large house he had rented in Sablons, was ready to sell. Despite his success at the 1937 [[Exposition Internationale des Arts et Techniques dans la Vie Moderne]], he lacked the funds necessary to purchase the house. In August, however, the American collector, Solomon R. Guggenheim purchased a large number of paintings directly from Gleizes, including his pre-war Cubist masterpiece, ''Le Dépiquage des Moissons''; a work he hoped would have been taken by a museum in France.[http://www.peterbrooke.org.uk/a%26r/a%26rintro Peter Brooke, ''Albert Gleizes, Chronology of his life, 1881-1953'']

{{About|the InterACT disability arts festival||Interact (disambiguation){{!}}Interact}}
{{Disability sidebar}} The '''InterACT Disability Arts Festival''' is an annual three-day event which showcases the talents of disabled performers, authors, artists, and artisans in [[Auckland]], [[New Zealand]]. The event has been described by the [[Minister for Disability Issues]], [[Tariana Turia]], as "a chance for people of all abilities to celebrate and share their talents with us all"<ref name="tariana">{{cite web|url=http://www.infonews.co.nz/news.cfm?id=79010 |title=Minister encourages wider community to support New Zealand's first Disability Arts Festival this weekend |publisher=Infonews.co.nz |date=2011-10-27 |accessdate=2013-09-20}}</ref>
==History== The festival was inspired by the [[Awakenings Festival]] of [[Horsham, Victoria]], Australia. It wasn't until five years after a visit to the 2007 Awakenings festival by three representatives of the Interacting Theatre Company, that the inaugural InterACT festival was held in Auckland, New Zealand.<ref>{{cite AV media |people=Chris Laidlaw, Chris Tally Evans, Paula Crimmens, Trina Armstrong|date=2011-10-30 |title=Radio New Zealand : National : Sunday Morning : 30 Oct 2011 : Ideas for 30 October 2011 |medium=Radio broadcast |url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/national/programmes/sunday/audio/2501301/ideas-for-30-october-2011 |accessdate=2013-09-20 |time=00:28:40 |publisher=Radionz.co.nz |quote=I work for Interacting, which is a disabled arts theatre company. And I went with Trina and our Chair[person] to Australia, to the Awakenings festival in 2007. It's taken us this long to decide we wanted to put on a festival, because essentially we're a theatre company and we do two productions a year. But last year we decided we were in a position with sufficient support networks and relationships with other organisations to go for it, and to put on a New Zealand version of the annual Awakenings festival in Australia. |ref= }}<!--{{cite web|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/national/programmes/sunday/audio/2501301/ideas-for-30-october-2011 |title=Radio New Zealand : National : Sunday Morning : 30 Oct 2011 : Ideas for 30 October 2011 |publisher=Radionz.co.nz |date=2011-10-30 |accessdate=2013-09-20}}--></ref>
The 2013 edition of the festival is scheduled for 23–25 October and the venue will be Corban's Estate Arts Centre, [[Henderson, New Zealand|Henderson]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://interacting.org.nz/interactfestival/ |title=InterACT Disability Arts Festival |publisher=Interacting.org.nz |date=2013-03-05 |accessdate=2013-09-20}}</ref>

:''This article concerns the painter Jean-Joseph Benjamin-Constant; for others like the European writer and politician see [[Benjamin Constant (disambiguation)]].'' {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox artist | name = Jean-Joseph Benjamin-Constant | honorific_suffix = | image = Jean-Joseph Benjamin-Constant photo.jpg | image_size = 150px | alt = | caption = Jean-Joseph Benjamin-Constant, ca. 1890 | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = Jean-Joseph Constant | birth_date = 10 June 1845 | birth_place = [[Paris]], France | death_date = 26 May 1902 | death_place = Paris | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = Painting, etching | notable_works = | style = | movement = [[Orientalism|Orientalist]] | spouse = | partner = | awards = | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = | module = }} '''Jean-Joseph Benjamin-Constant''' (also known as '''Benjamin Constant'''), born '''Jean-Joseph Constant''' (10 June 1845 – 26 May 1902), was a French painter and [[etcher]] best known for his [[Orientalism|Oriental]] subjects and [[portrait]]s. ==Biography== Benjamin-Constant was born in Paris. He studied at the [[École des Beaux-Arts|Ecole des Beaux-Arts]] in Toulouse, where he was a pupil of [[Alexandre Cabanel]]. A journey to [[Morocco]] in 1872 strongly influenced his early artistic development and lead him to produce [[Romanticism|Romantic]] scenes under the spell of [[Orientalism]]. Among his noted works in this vein are ''Last Rebels'', ''Justice in the [[Harem]]'' (both in the Luxembourg Gallery), ''Les Chérifas'', and ''Moroccan Prisoners'' (Bordeaux). His large canvas, ''[[:File:Benjamin-Constant-The Entry of Mahomet II into Constantinople-1876.jpg|The Entrance of Mahomet II into Constantinople]]'' (Musée des Augustins Toulouse), received a medal in 1876. [[File:Benjamin Constant, between ca. 1890 and ca. 1910.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Frances Benjamin Johnston]], ''Benjamin Constant'', {{circa|1890–1910}}, [[Library of Congress]]]] After 1880, he changed his manner, devoting himself to [[mural]] decorations and to [[portrait]]s. Prominent examples include the great [[plafond]] in the [[Hôtel de Ville, Paris]], entitled ''Paris Convening the World''; his paintings in the [[Sorbonne|New Sorbonne]], representing ''Literature'', ''The Sciences'', and the ''Academy of Paris''; and the plafond of the Opéra Comique theatre. He was distinguished as a portrait painter, especially in England, where he was a favorite of the [[aristocracy]]. His portrait ''Mons fils André'' (Luxembourg) was awarded a medal of honor at the [[Paris Salon|Salon]] in 1896. Benjamin-Constant painted [[Pope Leo XIII]], [[Alexandra of Denmark|Queen Alexandra of the United Kingdom]] (1901), [[Baron Savile of Rufford|Lord John Lumley-Savile]], and [[Henri Blowitz]] (1902). He was made a member of the Institute in 1893, and was a commander of the [[Légion d'honneur|Legion of Honor]]. He visited the United States several times, and painted a number of portraits. The [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York owns a large mural decoration by Benjamin-Constant entitled ''Justinian in Council''. Benjamin-Constant also taught; among his pupils was the miniaturist [[Alice Beckington]].{{cite book|author1=Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.)|author2=Carrie Rebora Barratt|author3=Lori Zabar|title=American Portrait Miniatures in the Metropolitan Museum of Art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YHKoX40qL7EC&pg=PA244|date=1 January 2010|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|isbn=978-1-58839-357-9|pages=244–}} He was a writer of repute, contributing a number of studies on contemporary French painters. Along with fellow artists, [[Alphonse-Étienne Dinet|Nasreddine Dinet]], [[Paul Leroy]], [[Jean-Léon Gérôme]] and curator/ art historian, [[Léonce Bénédite]], he was one of the founders of the [[Société des Peintres Orientalistes Français]].Benjamin, R., ''Orientalist Aesthetics: Art, Colonialism, and French North Africa, 1880-1930,'' University of California Press, 2003, p.57 He died in Paris on 26 May 1902. ==Gallery==

Josephmark (JM) is a digital product design [http://www.josephmark.com.au/ studio] and [http://www.josephmark.ventures/ venture lab] founded in 2004 in Brisbane, Australia. Currently, there are Josephmark offices in [[Brisbane]], [[Sydney]], [[Los Angeles]] and [[Stockholm]].
== History ==
Josephmark was formed in 2004 by current CEO Benjamin Joseph Johnston (co-founder of [http://www.gilimbaa.com.au/ Gilimbaa], [http://www.studiobreeder.com/ Breeder] and [[We Are Hunted]], which was acquired by [[Twitter]]) and Joshua Mark Capelin. In 2005, Jessica Huddart (co-founder of [http://www.sevenwithanother.com/ Seven With Another]) joined Josephmark as a Designer, before becoming Creative Director and co-owner in 2007, Director in 2014, then CEO in 2015.[[Josephmark#cite note-1|<sup>[1]</sup>]][[Josephmark#cite note-2|<sup>[2]</sup>]]
In 2016, Josephmark expanded to the U.S. and set up a second studio in Los Angeles, headed up by Executive Creative Director [http://alexnaghavi.com/ Alex Naghavi].<ref>{{cite web |title=Josephmark: Behind The Myriad Design |url=https://www.myriad.org/news/josephmark-behind-the-myriad-design/ |website=Myriad Blog |publisher=Myriad |accessdate=3 August 2018}}</ref> In 2017, Product Strategist [http://www.jaredfossey.com/ Jared Fossey] assisted in setting up a third location in Stockholm.
== Work == Josephmark’s clients include [[Red Bull]], [https://itunes.apple.com/au/app/tammy-fit/id1333303155?mt=8 Tammy Hembrow], [http://www.generalpublic.art/ General Public], [https://www.myriad.org/ Myriad], [http://www.josephmark.com.au/work/future-women/ Future Women], Melbourne Mint, [[Commonwealth Bank|Commonwealth Bank of Australia]], [https://languagemedia.com/ Language Media] and Interactive Media Holdings (the new [[Myspace]])<ref>Salter, Chuck (30 April 2013). [http://www.fastcompany.com/3009062/creative-conversations/join-us-here-for-a-live-video-hangout-with-the-brains-behind-the-new- "Join Us Here For A Live Video Hangout With The Brains Behinds The New Myspace: How To Design A Makeover"]. Fast Company. Retrieved 18 December 2013.</ref>.
Josephmark’s internal ventures include [https://clipchamp.com/ Clipchamp], [http://www.ridefrontside.com/ Frontside], [http://migolfclub.com/#/ Pin], [http://www.thisisvest.com Vest],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.afr.com/leadership/entrepreneur/josephmark-launches-vest--20160210-gmr3u0|title=Josephmark reveals top of the startup pops|date=2016-02-23|newspaper=Financial Review|access-date=2017-01-19|language=en-US}}</ref> [http://thehash.today Hash],<ref>Koh, Yoree (4 November 2014). [https://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2014/11/04/new-app-hash-attempts-to-better-organize-tweets-around-events/ "New App ‘Hash’ Attempts to Better Organize Tweets Around Events"]. Wall Street Journal. Retrieved 16 April 2015.</ref> (which raised $1M in private funding in 2016<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.afr.com/technology/josephmark-raises-1-million-for-catchup-news-platform-hash-20160718-gq85hf|title=Josephmark Raises 1 Million For Catchup News Platform Hash|last=|first=|date=25 July 2016|website=Australian Financial Review|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>) [http://www.airsickness.com Ourkin] and [http://undrtone.com Undrtone].<ref>Popescu, Adam (13 January 2015). [http://www.billboard.com/articles/6436623/entourage-music-supervisor-scott-vener-undrtone "'Entourage' Music Supervisor Scott Vener May Just Have the Next Big Music App"]. Billboard. Retrieved 16 April 2015.</ref> The Josephmark studio also curates [http://www.designoftheworld.com .W – the Design of the World blog], which has also been featured on siteInspire<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.siteinspire.com/websites/5442-design-of-the-world?utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=siteinspire|title=Design Of The World|last=|first=|date=|website=SiteInspire|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.
The studio have had websites featured on siteInspire<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.siteinspire.com/websites/7427-josephmark|title=Josephmark|last=|first=|date=|website=SiteInspire|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.siteinspire.com/websites/7497-josephmark-venture-lab|title=Josephmark Ventures|last=|first=|date=|website=SiteInspire|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, Siiimple<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://siiimple.com/josephmark/|title=Josephmark|last=|first=|date=|website=Siiimple|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, Sitesee<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sitesee.co/sites/joseph-mark|title=Josephmark|last=|first=|date=|website=Sitesee|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, CSSline<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cssline.com/go/Josephmark|title=Site In The Spotlight: Josephmark|last=|first=|date=|website=CSSline|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and CreativeBloq<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.creativebloq.com/features/10-great-uses-of-imagery-on-agency-websites|title=10 Great Uses Of Imagery On Agency Websites|last=May|first=Tom|date=22 September 2017|website=CreativeBloq|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, as well as being named one of the 100 Tech Companies To Watch in 2018 by The Martec<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.themartec.com/insidelook/100-growing-tech-companies-2018|title=101 Australian Tech Companies to Watch in 2018|last=Holderness|first=Alex|date=6 December 2017|website=The Martec|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.

[[File:NigdeMuseumSteleKeslik.jpg|thumb|300px|Keşlik Stele]] The '''Keşlik Stele''' is a [[Neo-Hittite]] monument from northern [[Tyana]], near [[Niğde]] discovered in 1962 in southern [[Turkey]], which dates from the 8th century BC.
== Discovery == The stele was discovered by Vural Sezer in the ''Bayındır Yaylası'' summer pasture of the village of Keşlik, a plateau north of [[Altunhisar]] in [[Niğde Province]] and was installed in the Niğde Museum. The location of discovery was part of the [[Iron Age]] [[Luwian]] kingdom of [[Tuwana]]. According to the testimony of local landowner Abdullah Tanik about the find, it was discovered by Turkish archaeologist Aykut Çınaroğlu in a 1962 survey. The stele had probably fallen from a hill which rises 25 m above the surrounding fields, since a depression has been found there which could have contained the pedestal of a stele. The monument is now in the [[Niğde Archaeological Museum]] and has the inventory number 51.
== Description == The brown [[Basalt]] stele is 1.45 m high, 69 cm wide and about 27 cm thick. The upper surface is severely weathered and pock marked. The image depicts the weather god [[Tarhunzas]] facing right. He is dressed in a short kilt, a short-sleeved over-tunic with a wide belt, and thigh-high boots. His head is bearded and he has shoulder-length hair, covered by a horned helmet. His right hand is bent at his side and holds a cluster of grapes, while his left hand holds a bundle of corn ears. Thegrape cluster and the corn ears both grow up from the ground on either side of him.
In the space to the right, between the figure and the corn ears, [[John David Hawkins]] detected nine lines of an inscription, which probably continued on the side of the stele. Because of the poor state of preservation of the stele, it was not legible.
The image is very similar to the depiction of the weather god on the [[İvriz relief]]. As a result, the Keşlik stele is dated to the same time as it - the reig of King [[Warpalawas]] of Tuwana (740-705).

This is a list of [[Feminism|feminist]] [[comic book]]s and [[graphic novel]]s.<ref>A feminist is generally defined as advocating for or supporting the rights and equality of women; see {{cite encyclopedia |dictionary=[[Oxford English Dictionary]] |title=feminist |url=http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/69193 |edition=3rd |year=2012 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |subscription=yes|quote=An advocate or supporter of the rights and equality of women. 1852: ''De Bow’s Review'' (‘Our attention has happened to fall upon Mrs. E. O. Smith, who is, we are informed, among the most moderate of the feminist reformers!’)}}</ref>
{{Compact ToC}}
==A== *''[[A-Force]]'' by [[G. Willow Wilson]], Marguerite Bennet, and Jorge Molina. A [[Marvel Comics]] series about an all-female team of [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Diaz |first=Eric |date=2015-05-19 |title=Review: Marvel’s A-FORCE #1 |url=http://nerdist.com/review-marvels-a-force-1/ |publisher=[[The Nerdist]] |accessdate=2015-05-22}}</ref> *''[[Anya's Ghost]]'' by [[Vera Brosgol]]. Graphic novel about a teen Russian immigrant girl who befriends a dangerous ghost.<ref name=Gilley140602>{{cite web |last1=Gilley |first1=Casey |date=June 2, 2014 |title=Reading List: A Field Guide to Fifteen Feminist Comics |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=53182 |website=comicbookresources.com |publisher=Comic Book Resources |accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>
==B== *''[[The Ballad of Halo Jones]]'' by [[Alan Moore]] and [[Ian Gibson (comics)|Ian Gibson]].<ref>{{citation |page=9 |title=Magic Words: The Extraordinary Life of Alan Moore |author=Lance Parkin |year=2013 |isbn=978-1781310779}}</ref> *''[[Batwoman: Elegy]]'' by [[Greg Rucka]] and [[J. H. Williams III]].<ref name=Gilley140602/> [[DC Comics]] graphic novel, originally serialized in ''[[Detective Comics]]''. A lesbian super-heroine faces a murderous super-villainess. *''[[Bitch Planet]]'' by [[Kelly Sue DeConnick]] and [[Valentine De Landro]]. [[Image Comics]] comic book series about a prison planet for "non-compliant" women.<ref name=Abad-Santos>{{cite journal |last=Abad-Santos |first=Alex |date=December 9, 2014 |title=Bitch Planet is the feminist comic book we’ve all been waiting for |url=https://www.vox.com/2014/12/9/7357259/bitch-planet-deconnick-review |journal=Vox |location= |accessdate=December 20, 2014 }}</ref><ref name=Thomases141219>{{cite web |last1=Thomases |first1=Martha |date=December 19, 2014 |title=Martha Thomases: Gifting Comics |url=http://www.comicmix.com/2014/12/19/martha-thomases-gifting-comics/ |website=comicmix.com |publisher=ComicMix Pro Services |accessdate=December 20, 2014}}</ref> *''[[Black Orchid (comics)|Black Orchid]]'' by [[Neil Gaiman]] and [[Dave McKean]]<ref>Cantrell, Sarah (2012). "Feminist Subjectivity in Black Orchid," in Tara Prescott, Aaron Drucker (eds.), ''Feminism in the Worlds of Neil Gaiman: Essays on the Comics, Poetry and Prose'', p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=HsBA_5hB__0C&pg=PA102 102].</ref> *''[[Murasaki Yamada|Blue Sky]]'' by [[Murasaki Yamada]]. [[Serial (literature)|Serial]] that depicts the economic struggles of a woman after divorce and the societal criticism she must ignore when she later lives with a younger man.<ref name="Stone Bridge Press, Inc">{{cite book|last1=Schodt|first1=Frederik L.|title=Dreamland Japan: Writings on Moderm Manga|date=1996|publisher=Stone Bridge Press, Inc.|isbn=9781880656235|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Loug6sbKTvEC&pg=PA155&vq=Feminist&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=3#v=onepage&q=Feminist&f=false]}}</ref> *''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer comics|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]''<ref name=Berlatsky130813>{{cite journal |last1=Berlatsky |first1=Noah |date=August 13, 2013 |title=Some of the Greatest, Most Popular Comic Books Are Feminist |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/sexes/archive/2013/08/some-of-the-greatest-most-popular-comic-books-are-feminist/278593/?single_page=true |journal=The Atlantic |publisher=Atlantic Monthly Group |accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>
==C== *''[[Carol Danvers|Captain Marvel]]'' by [[Kelly Sue DeConnick]] and [[Dexter Soy]]. The [[Marvel Comics]] superheroine was renamed from [[Ms. Marvel]], replaced her [[one-piece swimsuit]] style uniform with a more practical [[flight suit]], and became the source of her own powers, emphasizing self-sufficiency.<ref name=Gilley140602/><ref name=ArbeiterM2014>{{cite journal |last=Arbeiter |first=Michael |date=October 2014 |title=9 Fascinating Facts About Captain Marvel, The Studio's First Super Heroine |url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/46567-9-fascinating-facts-about-captain-marvel-the-studios-first-super-heroine |journal=Bustle |location= |accessdate=December 20, 2014 }}</ref> *''[[Castle Waiting]]'', by [[Linda Medley]]. [[Fantagraphics]]. Medieval fantasy series about a pregnant woman who takes refuge in a castle with fairy tale characters.<ref name=Edgar130122>{{cite journal |last=Edgar |first=Sean |date=January 22, 2013 |title=Castle Waiting: Volume I |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2013/01/castle-waiting-volume-i.html |journal=Paste |location= |accessdate=December 20, 2014 }}</ref><ref name=FlashlightWorthy>{{cite web |last1= |first1= |year=2014 |title=Graphic Novels: About Women. By Women. |url=http://www.flashlightworthybooks.com/Best-Graphic-Novels-About-Women/588 |website=flashlightworthybooks.com |publisher=Flashlight Worthy |accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>
==D== *''[[Death: The High Cost of Living]]'' by [[Neil Gaiman]], [[Chris Bachalo]], and [[Mark Buckingham]]. [[Vertigo Comics]] miniseries about a female [[Death (DC Comics)|Death]] taking temporary human form.<ref name=Gilley140602/><ref name=MartinR2012>{{cite book |last=Martin |first=Rachel R. |date=2012 |chapter=Speaking the Cacophony of Angels: Gaiman's Women and the Fracturing of Phallocentric Discourse |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=HsBA_5hB__0C&pg=PA11#v=onepage&q&f=false |editor1-last=Prescott |editor1-first=Tara |editor2-last=Drucker |editor2-first=Aaron |title=Feminism in the Worlds of Neil Gaiman |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HsBA_5hB__0C&pg=PA19#v=onepage&q&f=false |others= |location= |publisher=McFarland |page= |isbn=9780786466368 |accessdate=December 20, 2014 }}</ref>{{rp|19–20}} *''[[Dirty Plotte]]'' by [[Julie Doucet]]<ref>Chase, Alicia (2013). "You Must Look at the Personal Clutter: Diaristic Indulgence, Adolescence, Feminist Autobiography," in Jane Tolmie (ed.), ''Drawing from Life: Memory and Subjectivity in Comic Art'', University Press of Mississippi, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=1UycAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA225 225].</ref> *''[[Dykes to Watch Out For]]'' by [[Alison Bechdel]]<ref name=Chute2010p177>Chute (2010), p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=1Xc6QdyrQLAC&pg=PA177 177].</ref>
==F== *''[[Fun Home]]'' by [[Alison Bechdel]]<ref name=Chute2010p177/>
==G== *''[[Gemma Bovery]]'' by [[Posy Simmonds]]<ref>Constable, Liz (2002). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3190136 "Consuming Realities: The Engendering of Invisible Violences in Posy Simmonds's 'Gemma Bovery' (1999)"], ''South Central Review'', 19(4)–20(1), Winter 2002 – Spring 2003, pp. 63-84.</ref><ref>Watts, Andrew (November 2011). [http://search.informit.com.au/documentSummary;dn=627870527911451;res=IELHSS "Cracks in a cartoon landscape: Fragmenting memory in Posy Simmonds' ''Gemma Bovery''"], ''Essays in French Literature and Culture'', 48, pp. 45–65: "In reflecting on which elements Simmonds adapts and appropriates from Madame Bovary, Constable identifies Gemma Bovery as a feminist satire structured around metaphors of food, consumption, and gendered violence."</ref>

Univ. de Valencia |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi= |accessdate=December 22, 2014}}</ref> *''[[Persepolis (comics)|Persepolis]]'' by [[Marjane Satrapi]]. [https://books.google.com/books?id=1Xc6QdyrQLAC&pg=PA242 242].</ref> *''[[Pretty Deadly]]'' by Kelly Sue DeConnick and [[Emma Ríos]].<ref name=Gilley140602/> *''[[Princeless]]'' by Jeremy Whitley and M. Goodwin<ref name=Gilley140602/><ref name=Pfeiffer130111>{{cite web |last1=Pfeiffer |first1=Elisabeth |date=January 11, 2013 |title=Interview with Jeremy Whitley of Princeless |url=http://womenwriteaboutcomics.com/2013/01/11/interview-with-jeremy-whitley-of-princeless/ |publisher=Women Write About Comics |accessdate=December 20, 2014}}</ref> [[Action Lab Comics]] series. ==R== *''[[Rat Queens]]'' by Kurtis J. Wiebe and Roc Upchurch.<ref name=Gilley140602/><ref name=Ballou140617>{{cite journal |last=Ballou |first=Elizabeth |date=June 17, 2014 |title='Rat Queens' Comic Allows Female Characters to Kick Some Butt...With Clothes On |url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/28435-rat-queens-comic-allows-female-characters-to-kick-some-buttwith-clothes-on |journal=Bustle |location= |accessdate=December 20, 2014 }}</ref> [[Image Comics]] series. Four free-spirited female adventurers in a [[D&D]]-inspired fantasy setting. *''[[Red Sonja]]'' by [[Gail Simone]]. [[Dynamite Entertainment]] comic book series reimagining the fantasy swordswoman.<ref name=Gilley140602/>
==S== *''[[Sailor Moon]]''<ref name=Berlatsky130813/><ref name=Bridges140710>{{cite web |last1=Bridges |first1=Rose |date=July 10, 2014 |title=The Feminism of Sailor Moon |url=http://bitchmagazine.org/post/the-feminism-of-sailor-moon |website=bitchmagazine.org |publisher=Bitch Media |accessdate=December 20, 2014}}</ref><ref name=Kahn140714>{{cite web|last1=Kahn |first1=Juliet |date=July 14, 2014 |title=Nostalgia As A Weapon: The Sailor Moon Renaissance Is A Feminist Mission Behind The Lines Of Pop Culture |url=http://comicsalliance.com/sailor-moon-feminism-renaissance-nostalgia-women-role-models/ |website=comicsalliance.com |publisher=ScreenCrush |accessdate=December 20, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220003652/http://comicsalliance.com/sailor-moon-feminism-renaissance-nostalgia-women-role-models/ |archivedate=December 20, 2014 |df= }}</ref> *''[[Sally Heathcote: Suffragette]]'' by [[Mary M. Talbot]], [[Kate Charlesworth]] and [[Bryan Talbot]].{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} *''[[Sex Criminals]]'' by [[Matt Fraction]] and [[Chip Zdarsky]]. [[Image Comics]] series. A woman can stop time when she has an orgasm.<ref name=Gilley140602/> *''[[Shakmagia]]'' (''Jewelry Box'' in English), a feminist [[Egypt]]ian magazine, collecting political comics stories by different authors.<ref name=ElDeeb141120>{{cite news |last=El Deeb |first=Sarah |date=November 20, 2014 |title=New Egypt comic artists push limits of expression |url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/nov/20/new-egypt-comic-artists-push-limits-of-expression/ |newspaper=U-T San Diego |agency=Associated Press |location= |accessdate=December 20, 2014 }}</ref> *''[[She-Hulk]]''. [[Marvel Comics]] series about a female lawyer that gains green skin and super strength, that, depending on the writer, varies between a male fantasy, and a witty swashbuckler.<ref name=Gilley140602/><ref name=Rosenberg140521>{{cite news |last=Rosenberg |first=Alyssa |date=May 21, 2014 |title=She-Hulk is a feminist hero, not a male fantasy |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/act-four/wp/2014/05/21/she-hulk-is-a-feminist-hero-not-a-male-fantasy/ |newspaper=Washington Post |agency= |location= |accessdate=December 20, 2014 }}</ref> *''[[Murasaki Yamada|Shin Kilali]]'' by [[Murasaki Yamada]]. A semi-autobiographical story in which the protagonist, a mother of two whose marriage of ten years is slowly failing, eventually decides to find a job despite protest from her husband.<ref name="Stone Bridge Press, Inc"/> *''[[Suffrajitsu: Mrs. Pankhurst's Amazons]]'' by Tony Wolf with art by Joao Vieira. A Jet City Comics trilogy about the adventures of a secret society of martial arts-trained women, known as the "Amazons", who serve as bodyguards and field agents for the leaders of the radical women's suffrage movement in England during early 1914.<ref>http://suffrajitsu.com/</ref>
==T== *''[[Tamara Drewe]]'' by [[Posy Simmonds]]<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |year=2008 |title=Fiction Book Review: Tamara Drewe |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-547-15412-1 |journal=Publishers Weekly |publisher=PWxyz |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi= |accessdate=December 23, 2014}}</ref><ref>Ho, Elizabeth (Summer 2011). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/41302872 "From 'Having it all' to 'Away from it all': Post-feminism and Tamara Drewe"], ''College Literature'', 38(3), pp. 45–65, p. 46: "''Tamara Drew'' represents the experience of feminism as non-linear, consisting of sometimes overlapping, sometimes conflicting, histories."</ref> *''[[Tank Girl]]'' by [[Jamie Hewlett]] and [[Alan Martin (writer)|Alan Martin]].<ref>{{citation |work=Trash Aesthetics: Popular Culture and Its Audience |title=Regendered Reading: Tank Girl and Postmodernist Intertextuality |author=Imelda Whelehan, Esther Sonnet |pages=31–47 |year=1997 |isbn=978-0745312026}}</ref> *''[[This One Summer]]'' by [[Mariko Tamaki|Mariko]] and [[Jillian Tamaki]]<ref name=Gilley140602/><ref name=Dueben140507>{{cite web |last1=Dueben |first1=Alex |date=May 7, 2014 |title=Mariko and Jillian Tamaki Tell the Story of "This One Summer" |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=52651 |website=comicbookresources.com |publisher=Comic Book Resources |accessdate=December 20, 2014}}</ref> *''[[Tits & Clits Comix]]''<ref name=Williams2010p138>Williams, Paul (2010). "Questions of 'Contemporary Women's Comics,'" in Paul Williams, James Lyons (eds.), ''The Rise of the American Comics Artist'', University Press of Mississippi, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=902nWnHSXp0C&pg=PA138 138].</ref> *''[[Twisted Sisters (comic)|Twisted Sisters]]'' by [[Aline Kominsky-Crumb]] and [[Diane Noomin]]<ref>Williams (2010), p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=902nWnHSXp0C&pg=PA139 139].</ref>
==U== *''Umbral'' by [[Antony Johnston]]<ref name=Gilley140602/>
==W== *''[[Wimmen's Comix|Wimmin's Comix]]''<ref>Young, Allison J. Kelaher (2005). {{Infobox person | name =Ludwig Blum | image = Brno-Líšeň-Ludwig-Blum-plaketa-na-domě-Pohankova2-2013.jpg | image_size = | caption = Ludwig Blum Memorial plaque in [[Brno-Líšeň]] | birth_name = | birth_date =1891 | birth_place =[[Brno]], [[Margraviate of Moravia]] | death_date =1975 | death_place =Jerusalem, Israel | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation =Painter | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | box_width = }} '''Ludwig Blum''' (1891–1975) was a [[Margraviate of Moravia|Moravian]]-born [[Israel]]i painter. He emigrated to Israel in 1923, as part of the [[Third Aliyah]], and became known as "the painter of [[Jerusalem]]".
==Early life== Ludwig Blum was born in 1891 in [[Brno]], [[Margraviate of Moravia]].<ref name="rogallery">{{cite web|url=http://rogallery.com/Blum_Ludwig/blum-bio.html|title=Ludwig Blum - Biography|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="bonhams">{{cite web|url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/19622/lot/45/|title=Bonhams : Ludwig Blum (Israeli, 1891-1975) The Western Wall|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="jewish">{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishpress.com/sections/arts/ludwig-blums-israel/2011/12/29/0/?print|title=Printed from The Jewish Press » Blog Archive » Ludwig Blum’s Israel|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="museum">{{cite web|url=http://mobia.org/exhibitions/the-land-of-light-and-promise#slideshow5|title=Jerusalem and the Holy Land - MOBiA - Museum of Biblical Art|publisher=}}</ref> He emigrated to [[Mandatory Palestine]] in 1923, as part of the [[Third Aliyah]].<ref name="bonhams"/><ref name="jewish"/><ref name="museum"/> He served in the [[First World War]].<ref name="museum"/> He was privately educated in [[Vienna]] and later attended the [[Academy of Fine Arts, Prague|Academy of Fine Arts]] in [[Prague]].<ref name="rogallery"/><ref name="jewish"/>
==Career== Upon his arrival in Mandatory Palestine, and as a dedicated [[zionism|Zionist]], Blum started paintings scenes of everyday life and landscapes in Israel.<ref name="jewish"/> He did many paintings of Jerusalem (including the [[Western Wall]] and the [[Mount of Olives]]), [[Tel Aviv]], the [[Sea of Galilee]] and the [[Judaean Mountains]].<ref name="jewish"/><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yLQrEPLDkGAC&pg=PA277 |title=Tel-Aviv, the First Century|publisher=}}</ref> Additionally, he painted some kibbutzs: [[Kiryat Anavim]] and [[Degania Alef]], and the lives of Israeli soldiers, including the [[Palmach]].<ref name="jewish"/><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=amvQP0MzxRwC&pg=PA86 |title=Culture and Customs of Israel|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JJnFSDne_5EC&pg=PA268 |title=The Sabra|publisher=}}</ref> He also painted copper mines in the [[Timna Valley]].<ref name="jewish"/> He also painted the [[Arch of Constantine]] in [[Rome]], [[Italy]], and a vase of roses.
Blum became known as "the painter of Jerusalem".<ref name="bonhams"/><ref name="museum"/> In 1933, his painting entitled simply ''Jerusalem'' was honoured at the [[Royal Academy of Arts]] in [[London]].<ref name="rogallery"/> In 1967, he received the [[Yakir Yerushalayim]] from the City of Jerusalem.<ref name="rogallery"/>
In 2011 the [[Museum of Biblical Art (Manhattan)|Museum of Biblical Art]] in Manhattan held an exhibition of Blum's paintings.<ref name=MOBIA>{{cite web|title=Jerusalem and the Holy Land: The Paintings of Ludwig Blum (1891-1974)|url=http://mobia.org/exhibitions/the-land-of-light-and-promise#slideshow1|website=mobia.org|publisher=Museum of Biblical Art|accessdate=26 March 2015}}</ref>
==Death== Blum died in 1975 in [[Jerusalem]].<ref name="rogallery"/>
==Selected paintings== [[File:Ludwig Blum - Moshe Dayan, 1949.JPG|thumb|Portrait of [[Moshe Dayan]], 1949]]
*''Jerusalem in the Snow'' (1927).<ref name="jewish"/> *''Jerusalem, Temple Mount'' (1928).<ref name="jewish"/> *''Vase of Rose'' (1931).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/19303/lot/66/|title=Bonhams : Ludwig Blum (Israeli, 1891-1975) Vase of flowers|publisher=}}</ref> *''Kibbutz Kiryat Anavim'' (1932).<ref name="jewish"/> *''Kibbutz Degania'' (1934).<ref name="jewish"/> *''The Judea mountains'' (1943).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/19303/lot/79/|title=Bonhams : Ludwig Blum (Israeli, 1891-1975) The Judea mountains|publisher=}}</ref> *''The Arch of Constantine'' (1944).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/16940/lot/3091/|title=Bonhams : Ludwig Blum (Israeli, 1891-1975) The Arch of Constantine, 1944 9 1/2 x 13 1/4in|publisher=}}</ref> *''Jerusalem, seen from Mount Scopus'' (1950).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/paintings/ludwig-blum-jerusalem-seen-from-mount-scopus-5063534-details.aspx|title=LUDWIG BLUM (1891 - 1975)|author=Christie?s|publisher=}}</ref> *''The Market in Jerusalem'' (1950).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/paintings/ludwig-blum-the-market-in-jerusalem-5063542-details.aspx|title=LUDWIG BLUM (1891 - 1975)|author=Christie?s|publisher=}}</ref> *''View of Jerusalem from the Hill of Evil Counsel'' (1951).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/paintings/ludwig-blum-view-of-jerusalem-from-the-5255533-details.aspx|title=Ludwig Blum (1891-1975)|author=Christie?s|publisher=}}</ref> *''Landscape'' (1956).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/19303/lot/80/|title=Bonhams : Ludwig Blum (Israeli, 1891-1975) Landscape|publisher=}}</ref> *''Timna, Copper Mines'' (1957).<ref name="jewish"/> *''View of Jerusalem'' (1962).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/paintings/ludwig-blum-view-of-jerusalem-5108955-details.aspx|title=Ludwig Blum (1891-1975)|author=Christie?s|publisher=}}</ref> *''Jerusalem, David's Tower and the Sultan's Pool, seen from Mishkanot Shaananim'' (1964).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/paintings/ludwig-blum-jerusalem-davids-tower-and-the-5063553-details.aspx|title=LUDWIG BLUM (1891 - 1975)|author=Christie?s|publisher=}}</ref> *''The Western Wall''.<ref name="bonhams"/> *''The walled city of Jerusalem from the Mount of Olives''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/16919/lot/143/|title=Bonhams : Ludwig Blum (Israeli, 1891-1975) The walled city of Jerusalem from the Mount of Olives unframed|publisher=}}</ref> *''Sea of Galilee''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/21102/lot/189/|title=Bonhams : Ludwig Blum (Israeli, 1891-1975) Sea of Galilee|publisher=}}</ref> *''Portrait with a keffiyeh''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/19303/lot/67/|title=Bonhams : Ludwig Blum (Israeli, 1891-1975) Portrait with a keffiyeh|publisher=}}</ref>

==Further reading== *''The Real and the Ideal: The Painting of Ludwig Blum'' (Tel Aviv: [[Beth Hatefutsoth|Museum of the Jewish People]], 2009).<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D7PdZwEACAAJ&dq=%22Ludwig+Blum%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=tg27UrTPGsmO7QbXhIDgAg&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAw|title=The Real and the Ideal|publisher=}}</ref>
